case_name: Ram Prasad v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 530 of 1964 arises from judgment and decree dated December 19, 1962 of Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 78 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 530 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 19, 1962 of the Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 78 of 1961.

facts.text: Suit filed by Ram Prasad against State of Punjab for declaration that order of compulsory retirement passed against him was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate granted by the High Court of Punjab, arises out of a suit filed by one Ram Prasad, against the State of Punjab, for a declaration that the order of companypulsory retirement passed by the latter against Wm was invalid.

facts.text: Ram Prasad entered service as a Clerk in 1924 in Patiala Saddar Treasury in Patiala State.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Prasad originally entered serviced as a Clerk, in the year 1924, in the Patiala Saddar Treasury in what was then the Patiala State.

facts.text: Ram Prasad transferred to Patiala State Bank as Clerk on February 27,1984 Bk and confirmed in appointment.

anchor.surface_text: He was subsequently transferred in the same capacity to the Patiala State Bank on February 27,1984 Bk and was companyfirmed in his appointment.

facts.text: Ram Prasad promoted to next higher grade on September 1,1985 bk in Patiala State Bank.

anchor.surface_text: On September 1,1985 bk he was promoted to the next higher grade on the establishment of the Patiala State Bank.

facts.text: Ram Prasad promoted as Manager and posted to Bhatinda branch on April 1, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he was promoted as Manager and posted to the Bhatinda branch of the Bank on April 1, 1944.

facts.text: Ram Prasad promoted as Selection Grade Manager by Board of Directors on April 1, 1949 in grade Rs. 340-20-500-525-700.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1949 he was promoted as Selection Grade Manager by the Board of Directors of the Bank in the grade of Rs. 340-20-500-525-700.

facts.text: Ram Prasad compulsorily retired from service on September 23, 1953 but reinstated by Government on June 10, 1954 as order legally defective.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1953 he was cc mpulsorily retired from service but was subsequently reinstated by the Government on June 10, 1954 since the order was legally defective.

facts.text: Board passed order compulsorily retiring Ram Prasad on June 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On June 11, 1958 the Board passed an order companypulsoriy retiring him from service.

facts.text: Ram Prasad instituted suit in Court of Subordinate Judge, Patiala challenging compulsory retirement order.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Prasad challenged the order of companypulsory retirement passed by the Board on various grounds, by means of a suit institiuted in the Court of the Subordittate Judge, Patiala.

facts.text: Petitioner pleaded compulsory retirement order amounted to dismissal or removal under Art. 311 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: He pleaded that the order of companypulsory retirement amounted to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed Rule 27 of Bank of Patiala Staff Rules, 1954 illegal and void.

anchor.surface_text: He further maintained that r. 27 of the Bank of Patiala  Staff  Rules, 1954, hereinafter termed the Staff rules, under which the order of companypulsory retirement was made, was illegal and void.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Patiala found in favour of appellant on all but two issues and granted decree.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Patiala, framed appropriate issues. He found all but two issues in favour of the appellant and granted a decree substantially allowing the claims made by him.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Punjab High Court which allowed appeal and set aside Subordinate Judge's judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed an appeal in the High Court of Punjab which allowed the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Ram Prasad died during pendency of appeal in High Court; widow brought on record as legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal in the High Court Ram Prasad died and his widow was brought on record as his legal representative.

facts.text: Patiala Services Regulations first promulgated in 1908, revised 1931, re-issued 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Patiala State Regulations were first promulgated in the year 1908 and governed the employees of the State in matters relating to pay, allowances, leave, pension and travelling allowances.

facts.text: Patiala Services Regulations made applicable to Bank staff expressly in April 1941 except pension rules.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, in April 1941 these Regulations were made applicable expressly to the Bank staff of the Patiala state Bank by the Maharaja, with the exception of the rules relating to pension.

facts.text: Patiala became constituent unit of PEPSU on August 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1948, Patiala became a companystituent unit of the Patiala and ,East Punjab States Union  PEPSU .

facts.text: President of India assumed powers of Government of PEPSU on March 4, 1953 under Art. 356.

anchor.surface_text: On March 4, 1953, the President of lndia assumed the powers of the Government of PEPSU, in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by art. 356 of the Constitution.

facts.text: President issued Bank of Patiala Regulation and Management Order, 1954 on February 27, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On February 27, 1954, the President, in exercise of the powers vested in him in relation to PEPSU by the Proclamation, issued the Bank of Patiala Regulation and Management Order, 1954

facts.text: Board of Directors framed Staff Rules under cl. 4(1)(iii) of Regulation Order.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the powers companyferred Upon it by cl. 4 i  iii  of the Regulation Order, the Board of Directors of the Bank framed the Staff rules.

facts.text: President revoked Proclamation under Art. 356 on March 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By numberification dated March 21, 1954, in exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  2  of art. 356 of the Constitution, the President revoked the Proclamation issued by him under the said article on March 4, 1953.

facts.text: Regulation Order published in Gazette on March 14, 1954 but came into force on date made February 27, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: It is doubtless true that the Regulation Order, though made on February 27, 1954, was number published in the Official Gazette tiff March 14, 1954.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the companyclusions reached by us, this appeal must fail and is dismissed.

holdings.text: The Regulation Order came into operation on February 27, 1954, before the revocation of the Proclamation.

anchor.surface_text: By reason of the fact that the Order itself provides for its commencement as the date on which it was made, it is clear that the Order came into operation on February 27, 1954, though it was published at a later date. The Order was therefore made before the date of termination of the Presidents rule in PEPSU.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. 1(b) of the Order specifies it comes into force at once on date made; publication date irrelevant.

holdings.text: All clauses of the Regulation Order, including cl. 4(1)(iii), come within the purview of the saving clause in Art. 357(2) and continue beyond the specified period.

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be held that all the clauses of the Regu- lation Order, including cl. 4 1 iii , companye within the purview of the saving clause occurring in art. 357 2  of the Constitution and that they companytinue to be in operation after the period specified in that article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberal and extensive construction of 'things done' in Art. 357(2); provisions intend ongoing bank management; absurdity if lapsed after one year; harmonious reading of Order clauses.

holdings.text: The delegation to the Board under the Regulation Order did not lapse upon termination of President's rule.

anchor.surface_text: On this conclusion it follows that the delegation made by the President in favour of the Board of Directors of the Bank under the Regulation Order did number lapse on the terminatio of the Presidents rule in PEPSU.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from Regulation Order saved by Art. 357(2).

holdings.text: The Board was empowered under cl. 4(1)(iii) to frame rules on conditions of service including compulsory retirement.

anchor.surface_text: In the companytext in which cl. 4 1   iii  occurs, it is number unreasonable to companystrue the power to make rules vested in the Board under that clause as things done within the meaning of art. 357 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. 4(1)(iii) expressly includes power to appoint, remove, dismiss, lay conditions of service and frame rules.

holdings.text: Staff rules supersede Patiala Services Regulations as their application to Bank was an executive act revocable by competent authority.

anchor.surface_text: The act of extension being an executive act, there can be numberdoubt that it companyld be changed by a similar executive act. Therefore it is clear that what was changed or superseded was the extension and number the rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulations themselves allow change by competent authority; applied to Bank by Maharaja's executive order in 1941, not legislative.

holdings.text: Rule 27 does not violate Art. 311 as compulsory retirement after specified age/service is not dismissal or removal.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of r. 27 cannot, in the instant case, be assailed on this ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents (Moti Ram Deka, State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand); rule specifies minimum service/age; not punitive termination.

holdings.text: Rule 27 and Staff rules do not violate Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised by the learned counsel therefore fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Geographical/historical classification permissible post-States Reorganisation Act; cites Lachhman Dass v. State of Punjab.

holdings.text: Staff rules validly made by Board as majority of members sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with this view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporation law allows majority to act; applies to Board.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the conclusions reached by us, this appeal must fail and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings upholding validity of retirement order.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Saubhag Chand M. Doshi 1958 S.C.R. 571 A.I.R. 1957 S.C. 892

anchor.surface_text: The next decision in the same volume is the State of Bombay v. Saubhag Chand M. Doshi,  1958  S.C.R. 571 A.I.R. 1957 S.C. 892. This was a case of companypulsory retirement under r. 165-A of the Bombay Civil Services Rules as amended by the Saurashtra Government.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Saubhag Chand M. Doshi
precedents.cited_proposition: compulsory retirement under rule with age and minimum service does not amount to removal under Art. 311(2)
precedents.cited_holding: compulsory retirement is another mode of retirement if between superannuation age and minimum service period

precedents.citation: Lachhman Dass v. State of Punjab 1963 2 S.C.R. 353 A.I.R. 1963 S.C. 222

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in a series of decisions culminating in the judgment of this Court in Lachhman Dass v. State of Punjab  1  that after the enactment of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, different Acts in different parts ,of the same State companyld be sustained on the ground that the differentiation arises from geographical classification based on historical reasons. 1  1963 2 S.C.R. 353 A.I.R. 1963 S.C. 222.

precedents.case_name: Lachhman Dass v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: different service rules/Acts in different parts of same State valid due to geographical classification based on historical reasons post States Reorganisation Act
